data.title: Faculty Awards
data.meta_description: We turn curiosity into discovery, changing what we know about the world.
data.text:
Nobel Prize

David Baltimore, Physiology or Medicine, 1975

“for their discoveries concerning the interaction between tumour viruses and the genetic material of the cell”

Moungi Bawendi, 2023

“for their discovery and synthesis of quantum dots”

Jerome Friedman, Physics, 1990

“for their pioneering investigations concerning deep inelastic scattering of electrons on protons and bound neutrons, which have been of essential importance for the development of the quark model in particle physics”

H. Robert Horvitz, Physiology or Medicine, 2002

“for their discoveries concerning genetic regulation of organ development and programmed cell death”

Wolfgang Ketterle, Physics, 2001

“for the achievement of Bose-Einstein condensation in dilute gases of alkali atoms, and for early fundamental studies of the properties of the condensates”

Richard Schrock, Chemistry, 2005

“for the development of the metathesis method in organic synthesis”

Phillip Sharp, Physiology or Medicine, 1993

“for their discoveries of split genes”

Susan Solomon, Peace Prize, 2007

“for their efforts to build up and disseminate greater knowledge about man-made climate change, and to lay the foundations for the measures that are needed to counteract such change”

Samuel C.C. Ting, Physics, 1976

“for their pioneering work in the discovery of a heavy elementary particle of a new kind”

Susumu Tonegawa, Physiology or Medicine, 1987

“for his discovery of the genetic principle for generation of antibody diversity”

Rainer Weiss, Physics, 2017

“for decisive contributions to the LIGO detector and the observation of gravitational waves”

Frank Wilczek, Physics, 2004

“for the discovery of asymptotic freedom in the theory of the strong interaction”

Kavli Prizes

Ann Graybeil, Neuroscience, 2012

“for elucidating basic neuronal mechanisms underlying perception and decision”

Alan Guth, Astrophysics, 2014

“for pioneering the theory of cosmic inflation.”

Rainer Weiss, Astrophysics, 2016

“for the direct detection of gravitational waves.”

Crafoord Prize

Sallie “Penny” Chisholm, Biosciences, 2019

“for the discovery and pioneering studies of the most abundant photosynthesising organism on Earth, Prochlorococcus.”

Susan Solomon, Geosciences, 2018

“for fundamental contributions to understanding the role of atmospheric trace gases in Earth’s climate system”
